turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Ugh, I just got another batch of denials from Payer X. It feels like we're getting denied for everything lately! This one claim, specifically, for patient Jane Doe, keeps getting denied and I can't figure out why.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand your frustration. Dealing with denials can be challenging. I can help you look into that claim for Jane Doe. Could you please provide the claim number and the specific denial code or reason listed on the explanation of benefits (EOB)?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, thanks. The claim number is 123456789. The denial code is CO 29, which says 'The time limit for filing has expired.' But that doesn't make any sense! We filed this claim well within their 90-day timely filing limit. Their policy says 90 days, and we sent it in 70 days after the service date! How can it be denied for timely filing?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Thank you for providing the details. Code CO 29 indeed indicates that the claim was received beyond the payer's timely filing limit. While many payers have a 90-day limit, some may calculate this from a different date than the date of service, or there could be specific plan variations. It's also possible there was a delay in electronic transmission or processing.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: But their provider manual *specifically* states 90 days from the date of service for this plan type! We have the electronic submission confirmation showing it was sent on day 70. How can a transmission delay make *us* responsible? This is so frustrating! How do I even appeal this when I have proof it was filed on time?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: You're right, if you have documentation proving timely submission based on the payer's published policy, the denial for timely filing should not stand. My apologies if my previous response wasn't specific enough. For this situation, you should appeal the denial. Include a copy of the electronic submission confirmation report that shows the date the claim was sent, and cite the specific section in the payer's provider manual that states the 90-day timely filing limit from the date of service for this plan. You can also include a brief cover letter explaining that the denial appears to be in error based on your documentation. This provides concrete evidence for your appeal.
